Episode Title: Feeling stuck? Here's how to know when it's time to leave your job | Ada Chen Rekhi
Background: Ada Chen Rekhi is an executive coach and co-founder of Notejoy, a notes app for individuals and teams. She previously served as SVP of Marketing at SurveyMonkey and led marketing efforts for LinkedIn's growth team after her contact management startup was acquired by LinkedIn. She's known for her rapid career progression from entry-level at Microsoft to SVP in seven years and for her expertise in helping founders scale themselves through coaching.
Communication Style: Ada uses concrete frameworks and memorable metaphors (boiled frog, eating vegetables, curiosity loops) to make abstract concepts actionable. She shares vulnerable personal stories and specific examples from her coaching practice. Her tone is thoughtful and practical, often providing counterintuitive advice (like most people don't need a coach) while backing it up with structured reasoning. She emphasizes making advice contextual rather than generic.

Name: Adam Fishman
Keywords: activation, churn, conversion, experimentation, growth, metrics, onboarding, pmf, pricing, prioritization, product-market fit, retention, roadmap, subscription, user research

He's now an Entrepreneur in Residence at Reforge, runs an advisory practice, and writes the Fishman AF Newsletter. He's known for building high-performing growth teams and developing frameworks for growth strategy and execution.

He's direct and practical, using memorable metaphors like running through brick walls when there's a door right next to it. He balances humor with serious insights and isn't afraid to share his failures alongside successes. He emphasizes first principles thinking over pattern matching.

Name: Adam Grenier

Background: Adam Grenier is a growth marketing leader who built Uber's growth marketing infrastructure and team from the ground up as Head of Growth Marketing and Innovation. He later served as VP of Product and Marketing at Lambda School and VP of Marketing at Masterclass. He's known for pioneering the Growth CMO role and bridging traditional marketing with product-driven growth approaches.

Name: Adriel Frederick
Keywords: acquisition, activation, analytics, conversion, culture, experimentation, funnel, growth, metrics, onboarding, pricing, retention, revenue, roadmap, subscription

Previously, he was Director of Product at Lyft for five years leading marketplace and pricing teams, and before that spent four years as an early PM at Facebook on the user acquisition team. Originally from Trinidad and Tobago, he was the first Black product manager at Facebook and brings a unique global perspective to product development.
Communication Style: Direct and thoughtful with rich storytelling using concrete examples from his experience. Uses analogies effectively (algorithms as tools like screwdrivers, colonial tower metaphor). Balances data-driven insights with human empathy. Not afraid to share failures and lessons learned. Speaks with conviction about diversity and inclusion based on lived experience.

Name: Albert Cheng

Episode Title: Finding hidden growth opportunities in your product | Albert Cheng (Duolingo, Grammarly, Chess.com)
Background: Albert Cheng is a leading consumer growth expert who has led growth and monetization at three of the most successful consumer subscription products: Duolingo, Grammarly, and Chess.com. He started his career at YouTube working on streaming and gaming features for over 20 million users, and earlier at Google. His unique approach blends marketing, data, strategy, and product management, with a goal of running 1,000 experiments per year at Chess.com.

He uses analogies from his piano background (practice, feedback loops, structural foundations with creative expression) and specific metrics to illustrate points. Name: Alex Hardimen
Keywords: acquisition, conversion, culture, experimentation, funnel, growth, iteration, kpis, leadership, metrics, monetization, prioritization, revenue, roadmap, subscription

Episode Title: An inside look at how the New York Times builds product | Alex Hardiman (CPO, the New York Times)
Background: Alex Hardiman is Chief Product Officer at The New York Times, where she leads teams building news, cooking, games, audio, and advertising products. She has spent most of her career at the intersection of journalism and tech, including two stints at The New York Times (2000-2016 and 2019-present) and a pivotal role at Facebook leading news products right after the 2016 election. She's known for being at the center of major transformations, from helping The New York Times shift from print-first to mobile-first and launching their subscription model, to managing crisis-level product challenges during critical moments in news and democracy.
Communication Style: Alex explains concepts through vivid storytelling and concrete examples, often sharing behind-the-scenes moments from major news events. She's thoughtful and reflective, using metaphors like solar systems to illustrate complex organizational concepts. Her tone is both humble about the challenges and confident about the mission, frequently emphasizing the human impact of product decisions. She balances tactical product insights with broader philosophical reflections on democracy and journalism's role in society.

Name: Alex Komoroske
Keywords: a/b testing, activation, competition, culture, data-driven, experimentation, growth, leadership, management, market, metrics, monetization, persona, roadmap, strategy
Description: Alex Komoroske is a strategic leader who merges the practice, theory, and mindset necessary to tackle complex problems. He spent 13 years at Google, where he worked on Search and DoubleClick...

He also developed company-wide strategy alignment tools and later served as head of corporate strategy at Stripe. He's currently founding a startup focused on reimagining the web for the AI era. He's known for his systems thinking approach and unique frameworks for understanding organizational dynamics.
Communication Style: Uses vivid, unexpected metaphors and analogies to make complex systems thinking accessible. Speaks in parables that require listener engagement to complete the meaning. Often uses examples from nature, technology, and organizational dynamics.

Name: Alexander Embiricos

He's known for leading products at the bleeding edge of AI capabilities and for his vision of building AI teammates rather than just tools.

He's thoughtful and optimistic, often sharing provocative future visions like Tinder-meets-TikTok for agent decisions. Name: Alisa Cohn
Keywords: a/b testing, competition, culture, experimentation, growth, leadership, management, market, mission, monetization, okrs, onboarding, persona, revenue, vision
Description: Alisa Cohn is an executive coach who has worked with C-suite executives at startups like Venmo, Etsy, Wirecutter, and DraftKings, and Fortune 500 companies like Microsoft, Google, Pfizer, Dell,...
Episode Title: Scripts for navigating difficult conversations | Alisa Cohn (executive coach)
Background: Alisa Cohn is an executive coach who has worked with C-suite executives at both startups like Etsy, Wirecutter, Venmo, and DraftKings, and Fortune 500 companies like Microsoft, Google, Pfizer, and the New York Times. She was named one of the top 50 coaches in the world by Thinkers50 and the number one startup coach for the past four years by Global Gurus. She is known for providing specific, actionable advice and scripts for difficult leadership situations.
Communication Style: Alisa uses very specific, practical scripts and language that people can immediately apply. She speaks in a matter-of-fact, neutral tone when delivering difficult messages, emphasizing observable facts over judgments. She frequently uses real client stories and examples to illustrate points, and provides step-by-step processes. Her approach is direct but compassionate, always including elements of hope and support even in tough conversations.

Name: Ami Vora
Keywords: competition, conversion, growth, hiring, iteration, leadership, market, metrics, mission, onboarding, revenue, roadmap, strategy, user research, vision
Description: Ami Vora is the Chief Product Officer of Faire, which connects independent retailers and brands around the world. Before Faire, Ami spent over 15 years at Meta, including as VP of Product and...
Episode Title: Making an impact through authenticity and curiosity | Ami Vora (CPO at Faire, ex-WhatsApp, FB, IG)
Background: Ami Vora is Chief Product Officer at Faire, the most successful B2B marketplace connecting independent retailers and brands. She started at Facebook as a temp in 2007 (employee #150) after convincing someone to introduce her around the office for the price of a coffee. Over 15+ years at Meta, she launched the first Facebook developer platform, became Head of Product for the $55 billion Facebook ads business, oversaw ads introduction on Instagram, and most recently led product and design for WhatsApp (the world's largest messaging app with billions of users). She's known for her authentic, messy-and-imperfect leadership style, working out of her bathroom during COVID, and her signature response to disagreements: 'Fascinating‚Äîtell me more why you think that.' She writes The Hard Parts of Growth on Substack about normalizing that even great companies with great people face hard problems.
Communication Style: Disarmingly authentic and vulnerable‚Äîworks out of her bathroom, admits she loves to sleep and wastes time on absurd things, calls herself messy and imperfect. Self-deprecating humor ('how glamorous my lifestyle is'). Uses vivid, memorable metaphors (dinosaur brain, toddler soccer, hill climb, putting on the coat). Signature phrase: 'Fascinating‚Äîtell me more' (though she had to expand vocabulary because people caught on). Balances big strategic thinking with tactical execution focus. Rapid intellectual curiosity‚Äîassumes every person knows something she doesn't, sees every meeting as opportunity to uncover it. Normalizes hard truths (as you get senior you only make bad decisions, you get worse at everything because problems get harder) to remove burden of perfection. Posts dad jokes weekly at Facebook. Writes about 'The Hard Parts of Growth' to show that hard is normal even at great companies.

Name: Amjad Masad
Keywords: activation, conversion, culture, experimentation, hiring, iteration, management, market, mission, mvp, persona, pricing, revenue, roadmap, vision
Description: Amjad Masad is the co-founder and CEO of Replit, a browser-based coding environment that allows anyone to write and deploy code. Replit has 34 million users globally and is one of the fastest-growi...
Episode Title: Behind the product: Replit | Amjad Masad (co-founder and CEO)
Background: Amjad Masad is the co-founder and CEO of Replit, an AI-powered software development and deployment platform with 34 million users globally. He has been working on the vision of making software development easier since 2009, building one of the fastest-growing developer communities and AI products in the world. He's known for democratizing software development by creating an end-to-end platform that allows anyone, regardless of technical skill, to build and deploy applications.
Communication Style: Amjad explains complex technical concepts through concrete examples and real user stories. He uses analogies like factory lines and bottlenecks to make abstract ideas tangible. His tone is thoughtful and forward-looking, often acknowledging the seemingly absurd implications of exponential AI progress while grounding predictions in current observable trends. He frequently references specific user examples and quantifiable metrics to support his points.

Name: Andrew Wilkinson
Keywords: analytics, culture, growth, hiring, iteration, leadership, management, mission, monetization, mvp, retention, revenue, roadmap, strategy, vision
Description: Andrew Wilkinson is the co-founder of Tiny, a holding company that quietly owns more than three dozen profitable internet and consumer brands, including Dribbble and the AeroPress coffee maker.
Episode Title: I‚Äôve run 75+ businesses. Here‚Äôs why you‚Äôre probably chasing the wrong idea. | Andrew Wilkinson (co-founder of Tiny)
Background: Andrew Wilkinson is the co-founder of Tiny, a holding company that quietly owns more than three dozen profitable internet and consumer brands, including Dribbble (design community), AeroPress (coffee maker), and many others. Unlike traditional venture capital or private equity, Tiny buys and holds great businesses forever, partnering with founders who want to ensure their companies have a good home. Andrew has run 75+ businesses and has a unique perspective on what makes businesses work‚Äîoften it's the 'boring' ones that generate the most value, not the sexy startup ideas. He's known for contrarian thinking about entrepreneurship, focusing on cashflow and profitability over growth-at-all-costs.
Communication Style: Contrarian and direct, willing to say things that challenge conventional startup wisdom. Uses concrete examples from his portfolio of 75+ businesses. Self-aware about privilege and luck while also confident in pattern recognition from experience. Focuses on practical wealth-building over status signaling.

Name: Andrew Wilkinson
Keywords: churn, competition, conversion, culture, growth, hiring, leadership, management, market, metrics, pricing, retention, revenue, strategy, vision
Description: Andrew Wilkinson is the co‚Äëfounder of Tiny, a holding company that quietly owns more than three dozen profitable internet and consumer brands, including Dribbble and the AeroPress coffee...
Episode Title: I‚Äôve run 75+ businesses. Here‚Äôs why you‚Äôre probably chasing the wrong idea. | Andrew Wilkinson
Background: Andrew Wilkinson is co-founder and CEO of Tiny, a holding company often called the 'Berkshire Hathaway of the internet.' They own 40+ businesses including Dribbble, WeCommerce, AeroPress coffee maker, and Letterboxd. He bootstrapped from zero to hundreds of millions in revenue and was personally worth over $1 billion at one point. Started as a web designer at 19, built Metalab (design agency), then realized starting businesses was brutal and started buying them instead after reading about Warren Buffett. His approach: buy wonderful businesses with moats (brand, network effects) and leave them alone. Has started or been deeply involved in 75+ businesses‚Äînot something to brag about ('I've been an inch deep and a mile wide, which has been my Achilles heel'). Lost millions on failed ventures (pizzeria, designer cat furniture, online DJ school, skin cream, project management software competing with Asana). In 2020, got diagnosed with ADHD and went on SSRIs, which he credits as more impactful on his happiness than all his business success. Built an AI-automated life using tools like Lindy.ai to handle email, calendar, meeting prep, and more.
Communication Style: Reflective and self-aware, comfortable admitting mistakes and sharing failures. Uses storytelling and concrete examples rather than abstract theory. Blunt and direct ('that's kind of stupid,' 'I was a sucker running around like crazy') but in a friendly, conversational way. Mixes business wisdom with personal vulnerability (mental health, relationship advice, garbage-taking-out failures). Practical and tactical‚Äîconstantly shares specific tools, specific dollar amounts, specific actions. Draws heavily from Warren Buffett/Charlie Munger mental models. Self-deprecating humor about being 'an inch deep and a mile wide' despite success. Honest about what he doesn't know and comfortable saying 'I have no idea' about the future. Values simplicity and clarity‚Äîbreaks complex ideas down to fishing analogies.

Name: Andy Johns
Keywords: design, founder, growth, investors, management, mvp, persona, roadmap, startup, strategy, ui, user research, venture capital, vision, wireframe
Description: Andy Johns is a former tech exec and VC who had a successful run at several startups‚Äîincluding Facebook, Twitter, Wealthfront, and Quora‚Äîbut left it all behind a few years ago to take a...
Episode Title: When enough is enough | Andy Johns (ex-FB, Twitter, Quora)
Background: Andy Johns is a former VP of Growth and Product at Facebook, Twitter, Quora, and Wealthfront, where he was President and next in line to be CEO. After 17 years in tech startups and reaching the pinnacle of his career, he experienced severe burnout and stepped away from a high seven-figure venture capital role. He now works as a mental health advocate, sits on the board of Heroic Hearts Project helping veterans with PTSD, and helps burned-out high achievers through their mental health journeys.
Communication Style: Andy communicates through deeply personal storytelling, using vivid metaphors from nature and animals to explain complex psychological concepts. He's brutally honest about his own struggles, using specific examples like his panic attacks at Twitter and heart scare at 35. His tone is compassionate yet direct, often referencing spiritual teachers, literature, and research to support his points. He speaks with the authority of lived experience rather than theoretical knowledge.

Name: Andy Raskin
Keywords: culture, design, growth, hiring, jobs to be done, leadership, market, mission, onboarding, persona, revenue, roadmap, strategy, subscription, ux
Description: Andy Raskin helps CEOs align their leadership teams around a strategic narrative‚Äîa single story that powers success in sales, marketing, product, fundraising, and recruiting. His clients...
Episode Title: The power of strategic narrative | Andy Raskin
Background: Andy Raskin is a strategic narrative consultant who helps CEOs and company leaders align their teams around compelling stories that drive success across sales, marketing, product, and fundraising. He discovered his approach after his own startup pitch failed miserably, leading him to study screenwriting techniques and adapt them for business. He has worked with successful companies like Gong, Dropbox, Uber, Salesforce, Square, and IBM, and is known for his viral post 'The Greatest Sales Deck I've Ever Seen' about Zuora.
Communication Style: Andy uses vivid analogies and movie references to explain concepts, particularly Star Wars and screenwriting principles. He's direct and practical, often sharing specific examples from client work. He uses self-deprecating humor and admits when approaches don't work. His tone is conversational but authoritative, backing up principles with concrete business outcomes. He frequently references specific quotes from CEOs and real company examples to illustrate points.

Name: Anneka Gupta
Keywords: a/b testing, culture, design, experimentation, growth, hiring, management, market, monetization, persona, roadmap, strategy, ui, user research, vision
Description: Anneka Gupta is the Chief Product Officer at Rubrik, a leading B2B cybersecurity company. She previously spent 11 years at LiveRamp, where she was the President and Head of Product and Platforms...
Episode Title: Becoming more strategic, navigating difficult colleagues, founder mode, more | Anneka Gupta
Background: Anneka Gupta is Chief Product Officer at Rubrik, a leading B2B cybersecurity company, and a lecturer on product management at Stanford University's Graduate School of Business. She previously spent 11 years at LiveRamp, joining as one of their earliest employees (around person #20) and growing into President, GM, and Head of Product. She started her career as a software engineer after explicitly stating in her interview at LiveRamp that she wanted to become a product manager. During those 11 years at LiveRamp, she became the company's institutional historian, understanding deeply what had been tried before and why. She now teaches product management to graduate students at Stanford, which has helped crystallize her own thinking about the craft of product management.
Communication Style: Warm, thoughtful, and deeply self-aware. Frequently references her own struggles and growth journey ('I got this feedback in a performance review,' 'I had to change out all my direct reports'). Speaks in clear structures and frameworks but not in a preachy way‚Äîshares what has worked for her while acknowledging everyone's situation differs. Uses concrete examples from recent work and career history. Generous in giving credit to advice she received from others ('someone gave me this advice'). Very comfortable with vulnerability‚Äîshares journaling from age 13-23, physiological reactions to hard feedback, emotional waves. Creates space for others to be human‚Äî'it's natural to feel upset and defensive.' Highly empathetic and focused on understanding others' perspectives. Humor and levity are explicit tools she brings to difficult situations.

Name: Annie Duke
Keywords: acquisition, churn, culture, founder, hiring, investors, leadership, management, market, persona, revenue, roadmap, startup, ui, user research
Description: Annie Duke is a former professional poker player, a decision-making expert, and a special partner at First Round Capital. She is the author of Thinking in Bets (a national bestseller) and Quit:...
Episode Title: This will make you a better decision maker | Annie Duke (Thinking In Bets, former pro poker player)
Background: Annie Duke is a former professional poker player who won over $4 million in tournaments and is now a decision-making expert and author of bestselling books 'Thinking in Bets' and 'Quit: The Power of Knowing When to Walk Away'. She serves as a special partner at First Round Capital and spends her time helping companies make better decisions by applying insights from behavioral psychology and game theory.
Communication Style: Direct and practical with extensive use of concrete examples and stories. Uses analogies from poker and parenting to make complex concepts accessible. Emphasizes making abstract concepts tangible through specific processes and tools. Balances intellectual rigor with warmth and humor, often sharing personal anecdotes to illustrate points.

Name: Annie Pearl
Keywords: acquisition, activation, conversion, culture, funnel, growth, hiring, leadership, management, okrs, prioritization, retention, revenue, roadmap, team building
Description: Annie Pearl is the Chief Product Officer at Calendly. Previously, she was Chief Product Officer at Glassdoor, as well as Director of Product Management at Box. She was named one of the most...
Episode Title: Behind the scenes of Calendly‚Äôs rapid growth | Annie Pearl (CPO)
Background: Annie Pearl is the Chief Product Officer at Calendly, previously serving as CPO at Glassdoor and Director of Product Management at Fox. She transitioned into product management from law after joining a startup's founding team. She's known for scaling product teams through rapid growth phases and successfully transitioning companies from product-led to sales-led growth models.
Communication Style: Annie explains concepts through clear frameworks and real examples from her experience. She's direct and practical, often referencing specific percentages and data points. She uses analogies sparingly but effectively, preferring concrete examples from Box, Glassdoor, and Calendly. Her tone is thoughtful and strategic, always connecting tactical advice back to broader business principles.

Name: Anton Osika
Keywords: analytics, conversion, experimentation, growth, hiring, management, market, mission, mvp, persona, prioritization, revenue, roadmap, team building, vision
Description: Anton Osika is the co-founder and CEO of Lovable, which is building what they call ‚Äúthe last piece of software‚Äù‚Äîan AI-powered tool that turns descriptions into working products without...
Episode Title: Building Lovable: $10M ARR in 60 days with 15 people | Anton Osika (CEO and co-founder)
Background: Anton Osika is co-founder and CEO of Lovable, an AI software engineer that takes English prompts and turns them into fully working products in minutes. The company hit 4 million ARR in first 4 weeks, 10 million ARR in first 2 months, with just 15 people (now 18)‚Äîmaking it the fastest growing startup in Europe ever. Built by MIT grads in Sweden. Before Lovable, Anton was CTO at a YC startup when he created GPT Engineer, the most popular open source tool showcasing LLMs' ability to create applications (50K+ GitHub stars, dozens of academic references). GitHub initially shut it down thinking it was an attack when Lovable started creating 15,000 projects per day. The insight that drove him: enabling the 99% of people who don't write code to turn ideas into reality‚Äîhis mom doesn't code, most of his friends asked 'Anton, how do I find a great software engineer?' He saw cognitive labor being automated as the biggest change humanity will ever see. Rather than make engineers more productive (Microsoft Copilot approach), he wanted to empower non-technical entrepreneurs and enable a Cambrian explosion of new businesses and better software.
Communication Style: Thoughtful, mission-driven, slightly tired (always mentions the crazy pace and being tired from 10-hour days). Speaks in clear, simple terms but with technical depth when needed. Not prone to hype or exaggeration‚Äîgrounded and realistic about what's possible today vs future. Laughs easily, comfortable with vulnerability ('I'm a bit hard-pressed to find something that totally failed'). Uses precise language ('agentic' = giving the system more freedom to decide what happens next). Values clarity in prompting and communication‚Äîwill stop to correct misconceptions ('Let me correct you there‚Äîyou cannot use it on any existing code base'). Mission-focused more than ego-focused‚Äîconstantly brings conversation back to empowering users and enabling more people to build. European sensibility: slightly more reserved than Bay Area founders, but deeply ambitious underneath ('AGI timelines approaching').

Name: Anuj Rathi
Keywords: acquisition, activation, analytics, culture, funnel, growth, iteration, leadership, mvp, okrs, onboarding, pricing, prioritization, revenue, roadmap
Description: Anuj Rathi is the Chief Product and Marketing Officer at Jupiter Money, where he leads product management, marketing, design, growth, and analytics. Before Jupiter Money, Anuj served as the...
Episode Title: The full-stack PM | Anuj Rathi (Swiggy, Jupiter Money, Flipkart)
Background: Anuj Rathi is Chief Product and Marketing Officer at Jupiter Money, a neobank in India. Previously, he was Senior Vice President of Revenue and Growth at Swiggy for seven years, VP of Product at Snapdeal, Senior PM at Walmart Labs, and the very first Product Manager at Flipkart. He's known for building successful consumer internet products in India and developing practical frameworks for product management in complex marketplace environments.
Communication Style: Direct and framework-driven, using concrete examples and memorable acronyms. Explains concepts through practical stories from his experience at major Indian startups. Uses a teaching approach with clear, actionable frameworks that can be immediately applied. Balances contrarian opinions with pragmatic advice, often challenging conventional wisdom while providing alternative approaches.

Name: Aparna Chennapragada
Keywords: experimentation, growth, iteration, leadership, management, market, metrics, monetization, okrs, pmf, retention, roadmap, strategy, user research, vision
Description: Aparna Chennapragada is the chief product officer of experiences and devices at Microsoft, where she oversees AI product strategy for their productivity tools and work on agents. Previously,...
Episode Title: Microsoft CPO: If you aren‚Äôt prototyping with AI you‚Äôre doing it wrong | Aparna Chennapragada
Background: Aparna Chennapragada is Chief Product Officer at Microsoft, where she oversees AI product strategy for productivity tools and leads the work on agents. Previously, she was CPO at Robinhood and spent over a decade at Google as VP working on Google Lens, Search, Shopping, augmented reality, and AI Assistant. She was also a long-time engineering leader at Akamai and currently serves on the boards of eBay and Capital One. Aparna is known for her focus on zero-to-one product innovation, prototyping culture, and thinking deeply about interface design‚Äîespecially natural language experiences (NLX). She's also into stand-up comedy, which she sees as teaching many product lessons: knowing your audience, iterating on material, creating emotional resonance. At Microsoft, she's driving a 'live in the future' philosophy through programs like Frontier, where teams use cutting-edge unreleased AI capabilities to build products, creating a forcing function to understand what's possible next.
Communication Style: Thoughtful, self-aware, and comfortable with humor (she does stand-up comedy). Uses vivid metaphors (doing the splits like Van Damme, the AOL Dial-Up Modem Chatbot). Honest about failures (Google Now didn't work out but taught valuable lessons). Balances big vision with practical tactics (e.g., building a Chrome extension in 10 minutes). Frequently references specific examples from Google, Robinhood, Microsoft. Comfortable saying 'I don't know' or 'I built it' (the Chrome extension). Has a habit of testing ideas through comedy‚Äîshe's working on an AI stand-up set because it forces her to think about how people actually relate to these technologies. Warm, accessible, and deeply curious about what's next.

Name: April Dunford
Keywords: activation, experimentation, growth, hiring, management, metrics, mvp, positioning, pricing, prioritization, retention, revenue, strategy, subscription, team building
Description: April Dunford is a speaker, mentor, podcaster, best-selling author, and beloved returning guest to the show. Last year, she joined me on the pod to discuss product positioning and differentiated...
Episode Title: A step-by-step guide to crafting a sales pitch that wins | April Dunford (author of Sales Pitch)
Background: April Dunford is a speaker, mentor, podcaster, and bestselling author known for her practical frameworks on positioning and sales. Her first book, Obviously Awesome, became the definitive guide to product positioning, teaching companies how to make their differentiated value obvious to customers. Her second book, Sales Pitch, provides a step-by-step framework for crafting sales pitches that actually win deals. She has worked as VP Marketing or CMO for seven successful B2B tech startups and has positioned and launched dozens of products. She's known for taking complex strategic concepts and making them executable with clear frameworks that teams can actually use.
Communication Style: Clear, structured, and practical. Breaks down strategic concepts into step-by-step frameworks. Uses lots of specific examples from real companies. Direct about what works and what doesn't. Emphasizes execution over theory‚Äîgives you the workshop exercises, not just the concepts.

Name: April Dunford 2.0
Keywords: activation, experimentation, growth, hiring, management, metrics, mvp, positioning, pricing, prioritization, retention, revenue, strategy, subscription, team building
Description: April Dunford is the author of the must-read best-selling book Obviously Awesome, a definitive guide to product positioning. She spent 25 years leading marketing, product, and sales teams and...
Episode Title: How to nail your product positioning | April Dunford (Obviously Awesome)
Background: April Dunford is the world's foremost authority on product positioning and author of two bestselling books: Obviously Awesome (on positioning) and Sales Pitch (on sales methodology). She spent 25 years leading marketing, product, and sales teams for B2B SaaS companies, working with clients ranging from Google to Epic Games. Her expertise comes from hands-on positioning work with hundreds of companies, where she noticed a consistent pattern: most sales pitches were just glorified product walkthroughs ('click on all five dropdown menus'), with no actual positioning happening. She developed a framework to fix this, translating positioning into structured sales narratives that answer the fundamental question: 'Why pick us over the alternatives?' Her current mission is to get everything useful out of her head and into the world before she retires, focusing on delivering practical frameworks that unlock value for B2B companies.
Communication Style: Direct, practical, and refreshingly blunt. April cuts through marketing fluff to focus on what actually works in real sales situations. She uses vivid examples (Help Scout, LevelJump) and concrete before-and-after scenarios to make abstract concepts tangible. Her teaching style is conversational yet structured‚Äîshe'll walk you through a framework step-by-step, then show you how it plays out in a real pitch. She's brutally honest about what doesn't work ('everybody's sales pitch sucks,' 'category creation is overrated') and backs it up with data or decades of experience. Her philosophy has evolved to 'nothing's a big deal'‚Äîa zen-like acceptance of highs and lows, influenced by growing up in an entrepreneurial family (her dad ran a seasonal tourism business for 40 years with wild swings). She's in her 'get everything useful out of my head before I retire' phase, focused on creating frameworks that unlock value rather than entertaining readers. Her reflex when people say 'I enjoyed your book' is to correct them: 'I don't care if you enjoyed it‚Äîwas it USEFUL?'

Name: Archie Abrams

Archie has built one of the most counterintuitive and sophisticated growth engines in tech, characterized by long-term holdout experiments, optimization for total cohort value rather than retention rates, and a unique partnership between metrics-driven growth teams and taste-driven product teams. His father was an entrepreneur in technology whose empathy, curiosity, and kindness deeply influenced Archie's leadership style.
Communication Style: Thoughtful, self-aware, and intellectually honest. Frequently uses phrases like 'it's brutal' and 'unfortunately' when sharing hard truths about growth measurement. Balances big strategic concepts (100-year thinking) with specific tactical examples (payment failure notifications). Very precise with language - distinguishes between 'retention' and 'GMV,' 'rates' vs 'absolutes,' 'attribution' vs 'incrementality.' Often frames insights as learning journeys ('we used to think X, but we learned Y'). Generous with sharing what doesn't work ('this is the bane of my existence'). Uses analogies to angel investing to explain power law dynamics. References his father's empathy and curiosity as core to his leadership. Acknowledges messiness and tradeoffs rather than presenting a perfect system.

This 'disability became superability' is the foundation of his interview methodology. Communication Style: Fast-talking, enthusiastic, and generously self-deprecating about his learning differences while fiercely owning them as strengths. Curious to the point of offering to solve anyone's struggling moments on LinkedIn. Frames everything through product thinking (you are a product, culture is a product, jobs are products). Emphasizes agency and personal responsibility while acknowledging systems are broken.

Balances conviction ('we were right about News Feed') with humility ('we screwed stuff up'). Often frames things in sports or competition terms (his background). Loves discussing the non-romantic reality of startup life.

Shares vulnerable moments (getting blocked by CEO day before launch, throwing away 6 months of work, struggling with the pressure of maintaining writing quality after gaining traction). Builds narratives that connect personal experience to universal lessons. Often starts with 'I think' or 'I'd say' to soften assertions. Uses vivid examples (buying gift cards to save restaurants during COVID, 40 hours on a single post, long-pressing iPhone apps). Very generous in giving credit (calling Lenny top 0.1%, praising Tobi's vision). Speaks with measured pacing, taking time to think through complex topics rather than racing through answers.

This first-hand experience‚Äîwatching companies thrive on open platforms and then get crushed when platforms closed‚Äîshaped his understanding of competitive dynamics. Now at Reforge, he's transitioned from teaching courses on product and growth to building AI-native products like Reforge Insights, giving him a unique vantage point on how companies actually adopt (or fail to adopt) AI tools. He studies platform shifts not as abstract theory but as survival strategy, believing that distribution‚Äînot just great products‚Äîdetermines who wins.
Communication Style: Direct and systematic, with a strong orientation toward pattern recognition across platform shifts. Uses vivid historical examples (Facebook social gaming boom, Google's slow encroachment, LinkedIn's double cycle) to make abstract competitive dynamics concrete. Balances optimism about new opportunities with cold realism about how platforms inevitably close and companies get crushed. Not cynical about platform behavior‚Äîemphasizes these cycles happen due to competitive and capitalistic pressures, not because platforms are evil. Comfortable holding nuance: 'You have to play the game, but also plan your exit.' Uses frameworks and mental models heavily (four-step cycle, escape velocity, prisoner's dilemma) to create shared language for complex dynamics. Self-deprecating about predictions ('I could be wrong about ChatGPT being the winner, but I'm very confident about the cycle'). When discussing AI adoption, shifts to being more blunt about organizational dysfunction‚Äîwilling to call out hyper-realistic work-like activities and disconnected executives. Values coldly rational decision-making over emotional attachment. Grounded in operator experience, not just theory‚Äîhas built companies, run growth, now sells products to companies going through transformation.

Background: David Placek is the founder of Lexicon Branding, the pioneering firm that essentially invented the modern field of brand naming. Over four decades, Lexicon has completed 4,000+ naming projects and created iconic names including Powerbook, Pentium, Blackberry, Swiffer, Dasani, Sonos, Impossible Burger, Azure, Vercel, Windsurf, and CapCut. Lexicon has employed 253 linguists (mostly PhDs from Stanford, MIT, Berkeley) and maintains a network of 108 linguists in 76 countries. The firm has invested millions in R&D on sound symbolism‚Äîunderstanding what each letter of the alphabet evokes‚Äîand cognitive science research on how brains process brand names. Placek came from six years at a large advertising agency before founding Lexicon, realizing names needed specialization rather than being treated as an afterthought. He learned that large brainstorming sessions don't work‚Äînames come from small teams of 2-3 people working with disguised briefs. He champions boldness over comfort, believing humans only pay attention to what's different, not what's familiar.
Communication Style: Storytelling-driven and principle-based. Uses vivid examples from 40+ years of naming (Sonos, Pentium, Azure, Windsurf) to illustrate abstract principles. References unexpected sources: Melian Dialogues (ancient Greek text on asymmetric advantage), Andy Grove wisdom, grandmother's sayings ('rolls off my back like water off a duck'). Balances confidence with humility‚Äîknows the process works after 4,000 projects, but acknowledges luck plays a role ('by the way also, I have to say, there's some luck to this'). Patient teacher willing to explain linguistics and cognitive science accessibly. Uses metaphors and frameworks: winning diamond, three I's, red shoe among black shoes. Self-aware about not having psychology background despite deep psychological insights. Advocates for clients to be bold while acknowledging it's hard ('listen, this is not an easy task'). Diplomatic when pushing back on client ideas ('in very polite way, you're not going to know when you see it'). References research and data to support creative decisions. Emphasizes mission beyond profit: helping clients win, not just delivering good names.

She's known for her contrarian takes on growth tactics, her ability to pattern-match across companies, and her focus on sustainable growth engines rather than quick hacks.

Name: Elena Verna 4.0
Keywords: acquisition, activation, churn, conversion, funnel, growth, iteration, kpis, metrics, monetization, pricing, product-market fit, retention, roadmap, user research
Description: Elena Verna is the head of growth at Lovable, the leading AI-powered app builder that hit $200 million in annual recurring revenue in under a year.
Episode Title: The new AI growth playbook for 2026 | How Lovable hit $200M ARR in one year
Background: Elena Verna is the head of growth at Lovable, the AI-powered app builder that reached $200 million ARR in under one year‚Äîone of the fastest-growing companies in history. Previously, she led growth at Amplitude, Miro, Dropbox, and SurveyMonkey, becoming Silicon Valley's most sought-after growth advisor. But at Lovable, she's had to throw out most of her traditional growth playbook. The fundamentals of growth have shifted in the AI era: traditional activation optimization, paid acquisition channels, and incremental A/B testing matter far less than shipping features people want to talk about, building brand into every product interaction, and riding 'fast moving waters.' Elena is now evolving from data-driven growth to brand-driven growth‚Äîshe jokes that by the end of her Lovable journey, she'll be a 'growth brand person.' With 100 people delivering $200M ARR, Lovable represents a new operating model where engineering leverage replaces human headcount and growth happens through constant shipping, social amplification, and creating experiences that feel like superpowers.
Communication Style: Energetic, self-aware, and radically honest about what's working and what's outdated. Elena is incredibly transparent about throwing out her own playbook ('Hi, my name is Elena, I do brand now'). She's quick to contextualize‚Äîrepeatedly emphasizing that Lovable's growth is not a universal benchmark and depends on being in fast moving waters. Uses vivid language ('blow their socks off,' 'fire in their belly,' 'wired up') and isn't afraid to declare shifts ('Viability is left back in 2010s'). Self-deprecating humor about evolving from growth to brand. Balances excitement about what's working with realistic warnings about what can't be replicated in every context. Constantly connecting tactical changes to larger industry shifts (consumerization of B2B, cost of software dropping, AI enabling new operating models).

Name: Eli Schwartz
Keywords: analytics, conversion, freemium, funnel, growth, hiring, metrics, monetization, onboarding, revenue, roadmap, strategy, subscription, user research, vision
Description: Eli Schwartz is a leading SEO consultant and the author of Product-Led SEO. He has worked with industry giants like Zapier, Tinder, Coinbase, Quora, LinkedIn, and WordPress to build and execute...
Episode Title: Rethinking SEO in the age of AI | Eli Schwartz (SEO advisor, author)
Background: Eli Schwartz is a leading SEO consultant and author of Product-Led SEO. He has worked with industry giants like Zapier, Tinder, Coinbase, Quora, LinkedIn, WordPress, and SurveyMonkey to build and execute SEO strategies. Spent 7 years at SurveyMonkey where the company generated hundreds of millions of dollars annually from organic traffic. Known for challenging conventional SEO wisdom and advocating for a product-first approach to SEO rather than traditional tactics-focused methods. His career includes eye-opening experiences like realizing Mixpanel couldn't convert SEO traffic despite doing 'everything right' tactically, and helping Zapier develop their legendary programmatic SEO strategy. Has spent significant time analyzing how AI and LLMs are reshaping search, including reading the entire 286-page Google antitrust verdict to understand Google's dominance and competitive dynamics.
Communication Style: Direct and myth-busting‚Äîchallenges conventional SEO wisdom without hedging. Uses 'I think' and 'I don't know' when uncertain but has strong opinions based on experience. Shares vivid anecdotes from client work (Zapier, Tinder, Mixpanel, SurveyMonkey, Quora) to illustrate points. Self-deprecating about being 'biased' as consultant. Emphasizes 'it depends' is usually cop-out ('like a doctor saying you might be dying or need a nap') but then provides framework for how it depends. Hot takes delivered confidently ('Most SaaS shouldn't do SEO,' 'Restaurants shouldn't have websites,' 'Link building is mostly wrong'). Brings data and specifics (98% mobile market share, $10K/month agency costs, 286-page verdict, quadrupled traffic in 3 months). Repeatedly brings discussion back to product thinking and user journeys. Uses counterintuitive examples that stick (whenishanukkahthisyear.com, pizza shops with flash menus, Google Cloud shouldn't do SEO).

Emphasizes authentic human connection‚Äîmentions Ali Rao and Keith Henwood by name, talks about being an introvert who recharges alone. Direct about high standards without being harsh. Balances between being very senior (CTO) while staying approachable (office hours, AMAs, responding quickly to Slack).

Name: Eoghan McCabe
Keywords: competition, culture, growth, hiring, leadership, management, market, metrics, mission, onboarding, pricing, revenue, roadmap, strategy, vision
Description: Eoghan McCabe is the founder and CEO of Intercom, a customer service platform that has successfully pivoted to become an AI-first company with its agent product, Fin. After stepping away from...
Episode Title: How Intercom rose from the ashes by betting everything on AI | Eoghan McCabe (founder and CEO)
Background: Eoghan McCabe is the founder and CEO of Intercom, a customer service platform that successfully transformed from a stagnant late-stage SaaS business into a fast-growing AI-first company with Fin, their AI agent product. Studied computer science, worked as a software designer. Co-founded Intercom 14+ years ago with Des Traynor and others. Left CEO role in 2020 due to illness (mold toxins, tick bite) and burnout. During his absence, the company became bloated, lost focus, tried to do everything for everyone, and was five quarters from $0 net new ARR (negative growth). Returned in late 2022, one month before ChatGPT launched. Made authoritarian, top-down decisions: cut costs aggressively, picked service as the lane, bet $100M on AI, rewrote company values to be a 'sharp knife' (resilience, high standards, work hard, shareholder value first), created quarterly performance processes that led to 40% employee turnover. Within six weeks of GPT-3.5 launch, Intercom had a beta version of Fin. Today Fin is growing 300%+, mid-eight-digit ARR, will pass $100M ARR in under three quarters. Intercom is 15th percentile growth among 120+ public B2B software companies, predicting to be fastest-growing next year.
Communication Style: Self-reflective, centered, takes thoughtful breaths. Very honest and real about hard topics (ego death, therapy, being sick, running away, lowest Glassdoor rating, soft coups). Uses Irish humor and self-deprecation ('I credit wherever I am today, and I have decades of learning to go'). Comfortable with complexity and nuance ('I'm speaking out of both sides of my mouth here'). Acknowledges when things are his opinion vs universal truth. Frequently uses frameworks and first-principles thinking. Comfortable being provocative ('if you're not willing to work hard, hire a kid, you're in the wrong job buddy'). Balances big-picture mission with practical day-to-day reality ('corporate life kinda sucks'). Uses vivid imagery (wartime company, sharp knife, swashbuckling TinTin adventure vs reality). Generous with credit to others (co-founder Des, chief AI officer Fergal Reid, therapist Yosi Amram).

Name: Eric Ries
Keywords: a/b testing, acquisition, culture, experimentation, growth, iteration, leadership, management, metrics, mvp, prioritization, product-market fit, retention, revenue, roadmap
Description: Eric Ries is the creator of the Lean Startup methodology, author of the New York Times bestseller The Lean Startup, and founder of the Long-Term Stock Exchange (LTSE). He‚Äôs also a multi-time...
Episode Title: Reflections on a movement | Eric Ries (creator of the Lean Startup methodology)
Background: Eric Ries is the creator of the Lean Startup methodology and author of the influential 2011 book The Lean Startup. He coined and popularized terms that define modern startup culture: MVP (minimum viable product), pivot, validated learning, continuous deployment, vanity metrics, and innovation accounting. Before becoming a thought leader, he was a founder and CTO who blogged anonymously because blogging was considered career suicide. At IMVU, his team shipped products 50 times a day when monthly releases were considered advanced. He founded the Long-Term Stock Exchange (LTSE) to change how public companies are governed and measured, spending 10 years getting regulatory approval. His parents are doctors, and he was raised with deep respect for scientific thinking and truth. He's motivated by first principles thinking‚Äînot conjuring ideas in a cave, but through extensive trial and error, testing theories, and asking what success really means.
Communication Style: Honest to the point of radical transparency‚Äîadmits embarrassing details (blogged anonymously, got yelled at in meetings, own memory contradicted by physical evidence). Self-deprecating while confident in ideas. Uses vivid concrete stories to illustrate abstract concepts. Willing to admit when he's wrong and when theories need updating. Philosophical and spiritual without being preachy‚Äîtalks about ego identification, self-discovery through startups, human cognitive biases. Both defensive of his work (frustration with recurring misconceptions) and open to criticism (whatever works is the thing). Deeply moral‚Äîcares about whether ideas make world better, feels responsibility for how work gets used.

Name: Ethan Evans
Keywords: ai, analytics, conversion, design, engineering, growth, hiring, leadership, management, market, persona, platform, startup, ui, vision
Description: Ethan Evans is a writer, career coach, course instructor, and retired VP at Amazon. During his 15 years at Amazon, he helped invent Prime Video, Amazon Video, the Amazon Appstore, Prime Gaming...
Episode Title: Taking control of your career | Ethan Evans (Amazon)
Background: Ethan Evans is a retired VP from Amazon who spent 15 years building some of the company's most significant consumer products including Prime Video, Amazon Appstore, Prime Gaming, and Twitch Commerce. During his tenure, he scaled from managing 6 people to 800, went from senior manager to vice president, and holds over 70 patents developed during his Amazon years. He helped draft the language for Amazon's ownership leadership principle, specifically contributing the phrase 'An owner never says that's not my job.' Before Amazon, he didn't consider himself an inventor, but systematically taught himself how to invent. Now retired at 50, he coaches senior leaders and teaches courses on career advancement and breaking through to executive roles.
Communication Style: Direct and honest without sugar-coating, comfortable challenging conventional wisdom (managers should help you) and cultural norms (handshake business vs contracts). Uses vivid examples and personal stories to illustrate abstract concepts‚Äîthe database outage story with Jeff Bezos is seared word-for-word in his memory. Balances optimism (you can do this) with realism (some patience required, some things out of your control). Slightly contrarian but grounded in experience rather than theory. Self-aware about personality traits like stubbornness and not living in shame. Humble about contributions (saved email proof of ownership principle language but never told Jeff) while confident in insights.

Name: Ethan Evans 2.0
Keywords: ai, analytics, career, conversion, design, growth, hiring, leadership, management, market, persona, platform, startup, ui, vision
Description: Ethan Evans is a writer, career coach, course instructor, and retired VP at Amazon. During his 15 years at Amazon, he helped invent Prime Video, Amazon Video, the Amazon Appstore, Prime Gaming...
Episode Title: Taking control of your career | Ethan Evans (Amazon)
Background: Ethan Evans is a retired Amazon VP, executive coach, and course creator focused on helping leaders grow into executives. Spent 15 years at Amazon where he helped invent and run Prime Video, Amazon Video, Amazon Appstore, Prime Gaming, and Twitch Commerce (alone a billion-dollar business). Led global teams of over 800 people. Holds over 70 patents, all created during his Amazon tenure. Helped draft Amazon's 'Ownership' leadership principle, specifically contributing the phrase 'An owner never says that's not my job'‚Äîprobably the most impactful thing he's ever written, affecting 1.5 million Amazon employees. Interviewed over 2,500 people. Went from managing 6 people to 800 over 9 years ('just riding the elevator' as Amazon grew rapidly). Had a catastrophic public failure launching Amazon Appstore in front of Jeff Bezos, recovered, and was promoted to VP two years later. Now runs a popular LinkedIn newsletter, teaches Maven courses on breaking through to executive level, and coaches leaders on career development and leadership.
Communication Style: Direct, storytelling-driven, and self-deprecating. Uses vivid phrases ('Eye of Sauron,' 'operational cowboy,' 'Wile E. Coyote skid marks'). Not afraid to share massive failures (publicly failing Jeff Bezos on $100M launch) alongside successes (70 patents, VP promotion). Humble about privilege ('I've been very lucky, grew up upper middle class, retired at 50‚Äîwhat do I owe to pay forward?'). Teaches through frameworks and numbered steps (The Magic Loop is literally 5 steps, systematic invention is 3 requirements). Cites books constantly (Decisive, Leadership and Self-Deception, What Got You Here Won't Get You There, Almanack of Naval Ravikant). Brings receipts‚Äîkept the EMAIL showing he proposed 'an owner never says that's not my job' so he has written proof. Competitive streak ('I really want to analyze spots 1-5 on your newsletter rankings'). Bullheaded/stubborn ('even after Jeff Wilke told me he'd considered firing me, I just moved forward'). Christian but applies it practically ('to whom much has been given, much will be required‚Äîwhat's my social responsibility?'). Great at callbacks and threading stories through conversation.

Name: Ethan Smith
Keywords: b2b, conversion, design, founder, growth, hiring, management, market, persona, prototype, roadmap, startup, strategy, ui, ux
Description: Ethan Smith is the CEO of Graphite‚Äîthe leading SEO growth agency‚Äîand my go-to expert on SEO. After 18 years of mastering traditional SEO, Ethan has been at the forefront of what is called...
Episode Title: The ultimate guide to AEO: How to get ChatGPT to recommend your product | Ethan Smith (Graphite)
Background: Ethan Smith is the CEO of Graphite, the leading SEO growth agency, and has been in SEO for 18 years since 2007. He started in programmatic SEO with shopping comparison sites (NexTag, Shopping.com, PriceGrabber) during the era of mass auto-generated landing pages, experiencing firsthand the shift from 'SEO as spam' to 'SEO as quality' when Google introduced Panda. He brings the rare perspective of someone who has created both spam and quality SEO at scale, understanding exactly what works, what doesn't, and why. At Graphite, he works with companies like Webflow, MasterClass, and others, conducting rigorous experiments and original research to separate SEO myths from reality. His approach combines extreme intensity and aggression with zen craftsmanship‚Äîfocused, intentional practice at scale.
Communication Style: Intensely analytical and research-driven, but accessible. Brings rigor from academic research background (reproducibility, control groups, evaluating efficacy of AI detectors). Uses vivid examples (butter lettuce rankings for MasterClass, Otter + Zapier + BigQuery for Looker integration). Openly acknowledges his spam past in 2007 and why he knew AI content wouldn't work. Balances extreme intensity and aggressiveness with zen craftsmanship and flow state. Very tactical and specific ('pick the cheapest tracker,' 'subdirectory not subdomain,' '5% of landing pages drive 85% of traffic'). Debunks misinformation assertively ('Google is not dying, that's false'). Uses sports and climbing documentaries as metaphors for his approach. Self-aware about being competitive and nerdy. Makes complex topics concrete (voice share, RAG, model collapse).

Name: Fei Fei
Keywords: architecture, competition, culture, design, engineering, experimentation, founder, hiring, investors, market, mission, persona, prototype, ui, vision
Description: Dr. Fei-Fei Li is known as the ‚Äúgodmother of AI.‚Äù She‚Äôs been at the center of AI‚Äôs biggest breakthroughs for over two decades. She spearheaded ImageNet, the dataset that sparked the...
Episode Title: The Godmother of AI on jobs, robots & why world models are next | Dr. Fei-Fei Li
Background: Dr. Fei-Fei Li, known as the 'godmother of AI,' has been at the center of AI's biggest breakthroughs for over two decades. She spearheaded ImageNet, the massive labeled image dataset that sparked the deep learning revolution and ended the AI winter. She was chief AI scientist at Google Cloud where major early breakthroughs emerged, director at Stanford's AI Lab (SAIL), and co-founder of Stanford's Human-Centered AI Institute (HAI). She started working in AI in 2000 at Caltech during the AI winter when calling yourself an AI company was considered a death knell. Her PhD focused on visual intelligence and object recognition as a north star problem. She's been responsible for identifying that big data was the critically overlooked ingredient for bringing AI to life. She's on Time's 100 Most Influential People in AI, UN advisory board, and was on Twitter's board. Recently founded World Labs to build spatial intelligence and world models. Her journey spans from immigrant family running a dry cleaner at age 19 to becoming one of the most influential AI researchers shaping civilization-level technology.
Communication Style: Humble and inclusive‚Äîrepeatedly emphasizes AI is a 70-year field with generations of researchers, nobody got here alone, culture tends to assign achievements to individuals but it takes many heroes. Balances technical depth with accessibility for general audiences. Uses vivid analogies (Plato's cave for vision, teapot for object-level interaction, 20 watts for brain efficiency). Thoughtful and measured‚Äîpauses to get words right, gives nuanced answers rather than sound bites. Deeply humanistic‚Äîalways brings discussion back to people, dignity, agency, diverse roles in AI. Optimistic but not utopian‚Äîacknowledges AI will significantly impact jobs and has risks if mishandled. Generous with credit (mentions students, collaborators, inspirations). Mission-driven communication‚Äîwhether discussing technical breakthroughs or policy work, centers on human benefit and responsible development. Uses concrete examples (farmers, nurses, artists, accountants) to illustrate abstract principles. Speaks with quiet authority from lived experience across academia, industry, and startups.

Name: Garrett Lord

Episode Title: Inside the expert network training every frontier AI model | Garrett Lord
Background: Garrett Lord is the co-founder and CEO of Handshake, the career network for college students that powers hiring at 100% of Fortune 500 companies across 1,500+ colleges, 20 million students/alumni, and 1 million companies. The core business does $200M ARR and is the fastest-growing higher education company in history. In January 2025, Garrett launched Handshake AI from zero‚Äîa data labeling business that went from $0 to $50M ARR in just 4 months, and is on pace to blow past $100M ARR within 12 months. They're now the largest expert network in the world, working with 7 frontier AI labs including OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and Meta, providing high-quality post-training data created by 500,000 PhDs and 3 million master's students. Garrett's origin story: went to community college, paid his way through school, attended a no-name school in Upper Peninsula of Michigan, interned at Palantir which changed his life‚Äîand started Handshake to make opportunity accessible regardless of who you know, what your parents did, or what school you attended.
Communication Style: Energetic, passionate, mission-driven. Deeply believes in democratizing opportunity ('I want to make it easier for anyone regardless of who you knew, what your parents did, what school you went to, to find a great opportunity'). Grounded in hustle culture‚Äîtells story of sleeping in Ford Focus in McDonald's parking lots, showering in Princeton pool, driving 20-30K miles pitching schools. Balances technical depth (can explain RLHF, SFT, trajectory data, rubrics, multimodal) with accessible examples (PhDs breaking models, voice mode for new baby, educational design). Self-aware about being in once-in-a-lifetime moment and wants to meet it. Uses sports metaphors ('leave it all out on the field'). Generous with time for founders ('if anyone wants advice on how to start companies in AI, reach out'). Extremely loyal to team (shout-outs to Sahil, Young, Paco, Avery). Long-time Lenny subscriber since 2020. Intellectually curious ('love sucking up your interviews'). Celebrates impact constantly and creates fun environment.

His course at Stanford unexpectedly became less about tactical CEO skills and more about helping students figure out what to do with their lives‚Äîhalf of all student meetings are about this question. He won Stanford GSB's 2024 MBA Distinguished Teaching Award. As a teenager, he listened to motivational tapes while mowing lawns. In high school he quit wrestling after a big loss‚Äîhis biggest regret. In college he tried to row crew, failing year after year before having success his senior year. He lost money on Alpine's first fund, and 5 of his first 8 investments lost money. His first years teaching weren't good‚Äîhe was young and insecure. But he kept going. When his two oldest sons went to college (2022 and 2024), it hit him hard and launched him on a profound spiritual journey involving meditation and working with gurus.
Communication Style: Warm, confessional, and deeply honest about struggles and failures. Uses personal stories extensively‚Äîwrestling, rowing, financial exit disappointment, depression after achieving external success, sons going to college. Conversational without being casual‚Äîtreats serious life questions with genuine weight. Not afraid to share vulnerability: insecurity about teaching, losing money on investments, being 'not good' at things early on. References motivational speakers (Brian Tracy, Tony Robbins) and spiritual concepts without pretension. Frequently uses hypotheticals and thought experiments to help people access their own wisdom. Socratic‚Äîasks questions rather than prescribes answers. Frames advice as 'here's what I've learned' not 'here's what you should do.' Background: Ivan Zhao is the co-founder and CEO of Notion, a horizontal productivity platform valued at over $10 billion. Inspired by Douglas Engelbart's 1960s vision that computing should augment human intellect, Ivan became obsessed with the idea that there shouldn't be a separation between software builders and users. Background: Judd Antin has spent 15 years leading research and design teams at Yahoo, Meta (Facebook), and Airbnb. His direct reports have gone on to lead research teams at Figma, Notion, Slack, Robinhood, Duolingo, Fair, and other top companies, making him one of the most influential research leaders in tech. These days, he consults on UX strategy, org design, and crisis management, specializing in helping companies deal with organizational dumpster fires. He also teaches a class at UC Berkeley on leadership and writes at onebigthought.com, where his article 'The User Research Reckoning is Here' sparked intense debate across the research community.
Communication Style: Direct, opinionated, and unapologetically contrarian‚Äîcalls out sacred cows like NPS, design thinking theater, and founder worship. Uses strong language deliberately ('garbage in, garbage out,' 'broken system,' 'dumpster fires') to cut through politeness and spark real conversation. Self-aware about being provocative (chose 'reckoning' knowing it would inspire drama). Balances tough love with genuine care for the discipline and empathy for researchers stuck in bad systems. Academic in background (teaches at Berkeley, references sociology, survey science, behavioral economics) but practical in orientation‚Äîlots of concrete examples and specific techniques. Gives credit generously to teams and former reports. Willing to challenge industry darlings and 'obvious' wisdom (Henry Ford quote is apocryphal, AB testing doesn't tell you why, dog-fooding has blind spots). Values evidence over aesthetics of smartness.

Enthusiastically nerdy about psychology, experimental methods, and user behavior. Name: Lauren Ipsen
Keywords: design, growth, hiring, leadership, management, market, monetization, persona, roadmap, strategy, team building, ui, user experience, ux, vision
Description: Lauren Ipsen is one of the most well-known and respected executive recruiters in the industry, having placed over 90 senior product leaders at companies including Twitter, Reddit, Opendoor,...
Episode Title: Lessons from one of the world‚Äôs top executive recruiters | Lauren Ipsen (Daversa Partners, GC)
Background: Lauren Ipsen is a talent leader at General Catalyst, focusing on consumer and crypto portfolio companies. She started her career thinking she'd be in broadcast news but pivoted to executive search, finding it fascinating that she could work with all the companies she'd applied to (Twitter, Snap, Pinterest) from a different lens. She spent years at Daversa Partners, a boutique executive search firm, doing primarily consumer mobile buildouts for Twitter, Reddit, TaskRabbit, Nextdoor, Postmates, and others (85% of her work), with some more obscure roles (autonomous helicopters for Department of Defense, retail robotics). She's placed over 85 senior executives throughout her career. She then joined IRL as their first recruiting hire to build the talent function end-to-end (largely because she'd placed an incredible VP of Engineering there, Alex Strand, and wanted to work alongside him and learn the operating side). After that experience, she was tapped by General Catalyst, where she now splits her time 50% networking with great entrepreneurs and talent, 50% supporting GC portfolio companies. She's passionate about treating candidates as human beings and playing the long game in recruiting.
Communication Style: Direct, pragmatic, and relationship-focused. Uses vivid analogies (Instagram Reels vs. tagged photos, chief product officer of your household). Self-aware about recruiter reputations ('I feel especially passionate about this because recruiters have a bit of a reputation, and it's for some good reason'). Emphasizes humanity‚Äîremembers these are people with lives, families, ambitions beyond career. Honest about her own journey (tried to recruit whales early in career to prove herself, experienced bad recruiting calls when she was on the other side). Enthusiastic about great talent ('Alex Strand is just the most incredible, atypical, high emotional intelligent engineering leader'). Keeps notes on candidates (vests, conferences they're speaking at) to stay human and relevant. Not afraid to call out bad practices (logo collecting, lying on resumes, vague LinkedIn titles like 'Whatever at Reddit' that throw off recruiters).

Name: Madhavan Ramanujam
Keywords: acquisition, churn, conversion, growth, hiring, kpis, leadership, metrics, monetization, mvp, pricing, retention, revenue, strategy, subscription
Description: Madhavan Ramanujam is the world‚Äôs foremost expert on pricing and monetization strategy. As managing partner at Simon-Kucher, he helped over 250 companies, including 30 unicorns, architect...
Episode Title: Pricing your AI product: Lessons from 400+ companies and 50 unicorns | Madhavan Ramanujam
Background: Madhavan Ramanujam is the world's foremost expert on pricing and monetization strategy. As former managing partner at Simon-Kucher, he worked with over 250 companies, including 30+ unicorns, helping them architect pricing, packaging, and growth strategies. Author of 'Monetizing Innovation' (8 years ago) and now 'Scaling Innovation' (with Bill Gurley's foreword). Together with co-GP Josh Bloom, they worked with 500+ companies combined and 50+ unicorns at Simon-Kucher. He recently left Simon-Kucher to start his own venture firm, 49 Palms VC, focused exclusively on early-stage AI founders. His new model: get cap table access, roll up sleeves on all things monetization, invest in founder success with no fee-for-service friction. Fund One: 20-25 AI companies. His life motto: 'Create value in everything and anything that you touch. Everything else will follow.' His work shaped founder vocabulary‚Äîterms like 'price before product' and 'product-market-price fit' originated from his thinking. Thousands of founders over 8 years have made Monetizing Innovation a staple.
Communication Style: Direct, data-driven, systematic. Speaks in frameworks, axioms, and two-by-twos‚Äîmakes complex pricing strategy accessible and actionable. Uses specific examples constantly: Superhuman's $1/day framing, Intercom Fin's $0.99/resolution, Cursor's hybrid model. Loves creating memorable axioms that stick (20-80 axiom, price paralysis axiom, stop churn axiom). Not academic‚Äîdeeply practical. 'Go try this Monday morning' is common refrain. Structures thinking into checklists, tactics, strategies founders can immediately implement. Generous with knowledge‚Äîgives away enormous value for free, which creates reciprocity and builds reputation. Comfortable zooming between strategic (market share + wallet share philosophy) and tactical (how to taper concessions in negotiation). References 500+ companies and 50+ unicorns' data without being abstract‚Äîalways ties back to specific founder situations and trade-offs. Enthusiastic about pricing as craft and competitive advantage. Geeks out over details (42 axioms = Hitchhiker's Guide reference). Inspired by other founders (Clay from Sierra gave feedback on naming axioms). Creates nested frameworks‚Äîeach strategy has sub-strategies has tactics has specific moves.
