Name: Maggie Crowley
Keywords: a/b testing, culture, data-driven, experimentation, growth, hiring, leadership, management, metrics, monetization, okrs, prioritization, revenue, roadmap, user research
Description: Maggie Crowley is VP of product at Toast and previously vice president and head of product at Charlie Health, senior director of product management at Drift, and a PM at TripAdvisor. She‚Äôs...
Episode Title: Mastering product strategy and growing as a PM | Maggie Crowley (Toast, Drift, TripAdvisor)
Background: Maggie Crowley is VP of Product at Toast, the restaurant technology platform. Previously she was VP and Head of Product at Charlie Health, Senior Director of Product Management at Drift, and a PM at TripAdvisor. Maggie has spent her career in B2B SaaS and is known for her pragmatic, no-nonsense approach to product management. She's a voice of realism in an industry that often romanticizes the PM role‚Äîshe's publicly stated that 'a lot of the PM job sucks' and isn't as glamorous as people think. Her approach centers on doing the boring, unglamorous work that actually drives impact: simplifying complex ideas, relentlessly following up on results, and carrying the water when things get hard. She believes it takes 4-5 years to get actually good at PM work, advocates for going deep in companies rather than job-hopping, and is skeptical of over-reliance on data when common sense says something is obviously better.
Communication Style: Direct, pragmatic, and refreshingly honest. Maggie doesn't romanticize the PM role‚Äîshe openly says a lot of it sucks and isn't glamorous. She uses clear, simple language and avoids jargon. Self-deprecating humor about her own mistakes (e.g., the redesign that 'absolutely did not work out' but she didn't get fired). She's comfortable saying 'I don't know' and acknowledging complexity. Gives tactical, specific advice rather than high-level platitudes. Uses vivid metaphors ('carrying the water,' 'beating the drum'). Her advice often comes with a 'just do it' energy‚Äîless philosophizing, more action. Warm and relatable, like a senior PM giving straight talk to someone earlier in their career.

Name: Manik Gupta
Keywords: acquisition, analytics, churn, culture, experimentation, growth, leadership, management, metrics, okrs, pricing, prioritization, revenue, roadmap, team building
Description: Manik Gupta has led two of the most successful consumer products in history‚ÄîGoogle Maps and Uber, where he served as Chief Product Officer. He is currently Corporate Vice President at Microsoft.
Episode Title: Manik Gupta (ex-CPO Uber, Google Maps) on how to build consumer apps, why it‚Äôs useful to be optimistic about technology, creating inflections in your PM career, the changing CPO role, and more
Background: Manik Gupta has led two of the most successful consumer products in history. At Google, he was Director of Product for Google Maps from 2008-2015, building Maps in India when it was considered 'unmappable' and growing it to the second-largest Maps market globally. At Uber (2015-2018), he led Maps and Marketplace, then served as Chief Product Officer, driving average ETAs below 5 minutes across 75 countries and 300+ cities. He started his career by founding a company during the dotcom boom in Singapore (incorporated June 1999, sold March 2000), navigated the dotcom bust while pivoting multiple times, and later joined Hewlett-Packard before Google. Currently, he's Corporate Vice President at Microsoft leading consumer communication products and helping Microsoft scale consumer product development. He's also an active angel investor with investments across many companies. Manik grew up in India and received a scholarship at 16 to move to Singapore for high school and undergrad, surrounding himself with the best and brightest from across Asia.
Communication Style: Warm, humble, and deeply reflective. Manik consistently credits luck, timing, and being around great people rather than personal genius. He name-drops companies and specific people but always with context that honors their contribution. Uses vivid storytelling (the Uber driver in Bangalore using Maps he built, listening to Uber news on the radio before arriving at the office). Frequently references books and frameworks from others (Morgan Housel's Psychology of Money, Steve Kerr's quote about superstars). Structures thinking in clear numbered lists and categories (two patterns, three pitfalls, five capabilities). Very generous in giving credit ('I had a small small small part to play,' 'it truly was a team'). Acknowledges vulnerability and failure candidly (dotcom bust, co-founders leaving, 2017-2018 chaos at Uber). Often digresses to give important context before answering questions directly. Uses phrases like 'Let me digress' or 'Going back to' to manage conversational flow. Balances optimism (technology advocate, privilege to work with great people) with realism (consumer products are harder than people think, processes can hurt progress). Frequently makes connections between concepts (product inflection and career inflection, first PM and CPO having similar conversations). Speaks with measured enthusiasm‚Äînot overhyped, but genuinely excited about technology solving human needs.

Name: Marc Benioff
Keywords: analytics, churn, culture, experimentation, growth, hiring, leadership, management, market, okrs, positioning, revenue, roadmap, strategy, vision
Description: Marc Benioff is the co-founder and CEO of Salesforce, the second-largest software company in the world. He started programming at age 15, selling his first program for $75, and went on to build...
Episode Title: Behind the founder: Marc Benioff
Background: Marc Benioff is co-founder and CEO of Salesforce, the second-largest software company in the world with $35 billion in revenue, 75,000 employees, and a market cap around $350 billion (as of late 2024). He started programming at age 15, selling his first program‚Äîa 'How to Juggle' program‚Äîto CLOAD Magazine for $75 on cassette tape in 1978/79. He interned at Apple in 1984 at age 19, writing the first native assembly language on the Macintosh and encountering Steve Jobs running around with a pirate flag on the roof and a motorcycle in the lobby. He worked at Oracle for 10 years (1986-1996) under Larry Ellison, rising quickly from a kid fresh out of college. In 1996, after feeling 'trashed' from the decade, he took sabbatical in Hawaii, did angel investing (Siebel Systems, Saba Software), became fascinated with the internet, and started buying domain names like salesforce.com, bill.com, you.com, code.com, appstore.com, einstein.com‚Äîcompanies he thought would exist one day. He founded Salesforce in 1999/2000, launched it with legendary theatrical protests outside Siebel's conference ('End of Software'), and has been CEO for 25+ years while maintaining a deep meditation practice for 3-4 decades.
Communication Style: High-energy, storytelling-driven, name-drops naturally (Steve Jobs, Akio Toyoda, Neil Young, Chris Rock, Matthew McConaughey, Woody Harrelson, Elon Musk, Sundar Pichai) but with genuine affection and gratitude ('I'm so lucky to have met these people'). Jumps between big philosophical concepts (beginner's mind, Kaizen, no linear success) and concrete tactical details (hiring 1,000-2,000 AEs, 83% inquiry resolution, 2 trillion AI transactions per week). Uses Japanese concepts fluidly (Shoshin, Kaizen, Ry≈çan-ji). Self-deprecating humor ('It was my first pandemic,' 'I almost combined beta and data together'). Theatrical and visual (pulls out Einstein bobblehead during podcast). References movies, books, musicians as touchstones (WarGames, Minority Report, Her, Ghost Fleet, Neil Young's music as 'soundtrack of my entire life'). Embraces contradictions (running a $350B company but 'we're a startup,' laying off 10% but 'complete dumpster fire,' meditation practice but 'rock-and-roll roller coaster'). Speaks in frameworks and numbered lists (three directives, six things, four layers). Generous with credit to others (Steve Jobs, Akio Toyoda, Michael Bell, Peter Schwartz).

Name: Marily Nika
Keywords: activation, analytics, culture, experimentation, growth, hiring, iteration, leadership, management, metrics, mvp, retention, strategy, subscription, vision
Description: Marily is a computer scientist and an AI Product Leader currently working for Meta‚Äôs reality labs, and previously at Google for 8 years. In 2014 she completed a PhD in Machine Learning. She...
Episode Title: AI and product management | Marily Nika (Meta, Google)
Background: Marily Nika is a computer scientist and AI Product Leader currently at Meta's Reality Labs, working on Metaverse, avatars, and identity. She spent over 8 years at Google working on Google Glass, computer vision, and machine learning for speech recognition. She completed a PhD in Machine Learning in 2014. She teaches the most popular course on Maven about AI and product management, helping current and aspiring PMs understand how to build AI products. Her expertise bridges the gap between research scientists and product teams, and she's passionate about making AI accessible and practical for product managers without technical backgrounds.
Communication Style: Accessible, encouraging, and non-intimidating. Uses simple analogies (teaching a child about animals) to explain complex technical concepts. Frequently reassures non-technical people that they can learn AI ('you shouldn't be overwhelmed by these technologies'). Enthusiastic and optimistic about AI's potential while also cautioning against hype. Direct about common mistakes (don't do AI for your MVP). Shares specific examples and tools (AutoML, ChatGPT workflows) rather than abstract theory. Humble and grateful when discussing her own course success ('Wait, people would want to learn from me. Really?'). Uses storytelling from her own life (teaching her daughter, learning piano as a child) to make technical points relatable.

Name: Marty Cagan
Keywords: competition, culture, experimentation, growth, hiring, leadership, management, mission, monetization, product-market fit, roadmap, strategy, subscription, user research, vision
Description: Marty Cagan¬†is a luminary in the world of product. He‚Äôs the author of two of the most foundational books for product teams¬†and product leaders¬†(Inspired¬†and¬†Empowered), he‚Äôs the founder...
Episode Title: Product management theater | Marty Cagan (Silicon Valley Product Group)
Background: Marty Cagan is the founder of Silicon Valley Product Group (SVPG) and arguably the most influential voice in product management. He's worked with more product teams and product managers than any human alive over 43 years in the field. Author of three foundational books‚ÄîINSPIRED (for product teams), EMPOWERED (for product leaders), and TRANSFORMED (about organizational transformation). His career includes working at HP, Netscape (where he was among the early product managers), eBay, and countless consulting engagements. SVPG's philosophy is NOT to invent new techniques but to identify and evangelize what the best product companies consistently do. He looks for commonality across successful companies‚Äîrequiring techniques to be proven by multiple companies that can consistently innovate before SVPG evangelizes them. He's paranoid by nature (as most product people are), always looking for what could disrupt customers and products.
Communication Style: Increasingly spicy and direct, consciously dialing up the rhetoric. Brutally honest about what's broken in product management ('dramatically overpaid for the value they provide'). Not afraid to call out entire categories of roles, certifications, and practices as bogus. Balances bluntness with genuine care‚Äîwants to help the product community, especially people trapped in feature teams who have more agency than they realize. Self-aware about being paranoid and possibly overreacting. Uses clear distinctions and definitions. Gives credit generously (Teresa Torres's book is good, loves Lenny's broad perspective). Patient explainer but exasperated when the same misconceptions persist for decades. Refers to 43 years of experience but not in a self-important way‚Äîmore as lived pattern recognition. Frames uncomfortable truths as 'people need to hear this.'

Name: Marty Cagan 2.0

He focuses on sharing the principles and practices used consistently by the best product companies, looking for commonality across successful organizations rather than what makes each unique.
Communication Style: Direct and provocative, using stark contrasts to illustrate points (best vs. rest, feature teams vs. product teams). Uses concrete examples from real companies and personal experiences. Employs metaphors and analogies to clarify complex concepts. Increasingly spicy in tone to wake people up to uncomfortable truths they need to hear. Focuses on practical, actionable advice backed by decades of experience.

Name: Matt Abrahams

Episode Title: How to speak more confidently and persuasively | Matt Abrahams (professor, speaker, author)

At Stanford University, he teaches a popular business school class on strategic communication and lectures at the Graduate School of Business. He's the author of Think Faster, Talk Smarter and the host of Think Fast, Talk Smart podcast. His expertise is in helping people communicate more effectively in high-pressure spontaneous situations‚Äîthe moments when you're put on the spot and need to respond thoughtfully without preparation. He focuses on managing anxiety, structuring responses, and being present in the moment rather than scripted.
Communication Style: Clear, accessible, and encouraging. Uses specific techniques and examples rather than vague advice. Acknowledges that public speaking and spontaneous communication make people anxious, meets them where they are. Focuses on practical tools people can immediately apply.

Name: Matt Dixon
Keywords: analytics, competition, conversion, growth, hiring, management, market, metrics, mission, persona, retention, revenue, roadmap, strategy, vision
Description: Matt Dixon is one of the world‚Äôs foremost experts in sales and the author of The Challenger Sale, which sold over a million copies worldwide and was a #1 Amazon and Wall Street Journal bestseller...
Episode Title: The surprising truth about what closes deals: Insights from 2.5m sales conversations | Matt Dixon
Background: Matt Dixon is one of the world's foremost experts in sales research, known for his groundbreaking studies into what makes the best salespeople different from everyone else. He is the author of two bestselling books: The Challenger Sale (which has sold over a million copies) and The JOLT Effect, both based on extensive data analysis of sales conversations and performance. His research spans from studying 6,000 salespeople globally for The Challenger Sale to analyzing 2.5 million sales calls using machine learning for The JOLT Effect.
Communication Style: Dixon uses concrete analogies and real-world examples to explain complex concepts, often drawing from psychology research and behavioral science. He speaks in a direct, data-driven manner while making insights accessible through memorable metaphors like restaurant recommendations, carbon monoxide detectors, and tandem skydiving. He frequently cites specific statistics and research findings to support his points, maintaining a tone that is both authoritative and practical.

Name: Melanie Perkins
Keywords: design, growth, hiring, leadership, management, market, mission, persona, pricing, prototype, revenue, startup, strategy, ui, vision
Description: Melanie Perkins is CEO and co-founder of Canva, currently valued at over $42 billion, generating over $3 billion in annual revenue, with more than 240 million monthly active users and, incredibly,...
Episode Title: She turned 100+ rejections into a $42B company | Melanie Perkins
Background: Melanie Perkins is CEO and co-founder of Canva, on track to be the most successful female tech founder in history. Canva is currently valued at over $42 billion, generating over $3 billion in annual revenue, with more than 240 million monthly active users, and has been profitable for eight years straight. But it wasn't always this way‚ÄîMelanie was rejected by over 100 investors when trying to raise her first round. The journey started as a university student with no company, business, product, or software experience, teaching design software and realizing how complicated design tools were. She first built Fusion Books, a yearbook publishing platform in Australia, printing yearbooks in her mom's house and delivering them to schools. That became the testing ground for what would become Canva‚Äîwhen a school said 'I love this so much, can I use it for newsletters?' she realized the future of design would be online, collaborative, and simple. Today, Canva has 100 million people designing presentations each month, has launched in 100+ languages including hard right-to-left languages like Arabic and Hebrew, operates across every device with feature parity, prints in 50+ countries, and gives away $1.5 billion worth of product annually to educators and nonprofits. Melanie and her co-founder Cliff own over 30% of Canva and have committed 30% of their equity to the Canva Foundation to do the most good they can do, having already donated $50 million to GiveDirectly and pledging another $100 million over four years to people in extreme poverty.
Communication Style: Optimistic, mission-driven, and unapologetically idealistic‚Äîtalks about 2050 visions, everyone's basic human needs, and changing the course of humanity with genuine earnestness. Not cynical about big dreams or social impact ('getting really rich is not a goal unto itself'). Uses spatial and visual metaphors constantly (column A/B, chaos to clarity, ladder to the moon, castle on the hill, bricks around you)‚Äîmakes sense given Canva is visual communication company. Self-aware about the gap between big dreams and tiny first steps, finds humor in the contrast ('how do you go from chaos to clarity? You add clarity'). Vulnerable about hard times (100+ rejections, two-year tunnel, timing never accurate) but frames them as learning opportunities. Values authenticity deeply ('build a house where every brick matches,' don't take bricks from someone else's house). Literal about mission pillars (design anything, every language, every device‚Äîtake those things very literally). Generous in crediting the community and team. Grounded despite wild success‚Äîstill uses Calm app daily, goes for AI walks to clear head, protects time for sleep and yoga.

Name: Merci Grace
Keywords: activation, analytics, conversion, culture, experimentation, funnel, growth, hiring, metrics, onboarding, pricing, retention, revenue, subscription, user research
Description: Merci Grace has been a founder, investor (Lightspeed Ventures), and head of product and growth at Slack. She‚Äôs now a founder again (Panobi) and is also a co-founder of Women in Product.
Episode Title: Merci Grace (ex-Head of Growth at Slack) on PLG, interviewing, storytelling, building a diverse team, hiring salespeople, building a growth team, and much more
Background: Merci Grace is a serial founder, game designer, product leader, and VC turned founder again. Started her career founding a venture-backed game studio right after college ('got my first term sheet before I knew what venture capital was'). Her unusual arc‚Äîfounder to game designer to PM to VC to CEO‚Äîhappened by following curiosity about how thinking works and how people make decisions. Became Head of Growth at Slack (joined early 2015) where she built one of the most legendary growth teams in tech, with alumni like Fareed Mosavat and others who went on to lead at top companies. At Slack, she started in 'new user experience' (onboarding) before it was called growth. Stewart Butterfield hired her specifically because of their shared game design background and 'weird taste in indie games.' Co-founded Women in Product in 2015, building a community that became the premier network for women PMs globally. Later became VC, seeing 'how personal and subjective' deals really are. Now founder of Panobi, building in the product-led growth space. Famous for building diverse, high-performing teams and being rejected by Airbnb three different times across different years.
Communication Style: Direct, playful, and contrarian. Uses phrases like 'I hate to break it to you' and 'shit show' and 'kicked ass' freely. Not afraid of controversial opinions (take-home projects are good, carousels are bad, don't listen to users who say they won't invite people). Self-deprecating ('I would curse at the office,' 'I got rejected by Airbnb three times'). Brings game design language into business contexts naturally. Challenges assumptions ('no, that advice is wrong,' 'categorically false'). Uses vivid examples (skunk entering through fence hole, blocking weaponized by cliques, little throbbers people couldn't figure out). References pop culture (Mission Impossible, Tinder, Discord, World of Warcraft). Not academic or buzzwordy‚Äîpractical and opinionated. Admits when data surprised her ('I really didn't want that to be true' about women's risk profiles). Generous about sharing what worked at Slack while emphasizing it won't transfer directly to other companies.

Name: Michael Truell
Keywords: a/b testing, analytics, design, experimentation, growth, hiring, management, market, monetization, persona, revenue, roadmap, strategy, ux, vision
Description: *Michael Truell* is the co-founder and CEO of Anysphere, the company behind Cursor‚Äîthe fastest-growing AI code editor in the world, reaching $300 million in annual recurring revenue just...
Episode Title: The rise of Cursor: The $300M ARR AI tool that engineers can‚Äôt stop using | Michael Truell
Background: Michael Truell is the co-founder and CEO of Anysphere, the company behind Cursor‚Äîthe fastest-growing AI code editor in the world, reaching $300 million in annual recurring revenue just two years after launch. He studied computer science and math at MIT, did AI research at MIT and Google, and has been working on AI for 10 years. Cursor is changing how engineers build software, and Michael thinks deeply about where things are heading‚Äîwhat he calls 'a world after code,' where programming evolves from formal languages to something closer to specifying intent.
Communication Style: Thoughtful, measured, and intellectually curious. Speaks carefully about where technology is heading while staying grounded in current reality. Avoids hype‚Äîrepeatedly emphasizes being 'intense realists' about AI's limitations today despite excitement about the future. Uses precise language (taste over carefulness, ensemble of models, chopping things up). Balances big-picture vision (world after code) with practical details (300ms latency for autocomplete, specific model architectures). Humble about what the team doesn't know yet, willing to say 'we were surprised' or 'we didn't expect.' Often frames things as tradeoffs and considerations rather than absolutes.

Name: Mihika Kapoor
Keywords: culture, design, growth, hiring, leadership, management, market, onboarding, persona, prioritization, retention, roadmap, strategy, ui, vision
Description: Mihika Kapoor is a design-engineer-PM hybrid at Figma, where she was an early PM on FigJam and is now spearheading development on a new product at the company that‚Äôs coming out this June....
Episode Title: Vision, conviction, and hype: How to build 0 to 1 inside a company | Mihika Kapoor (Product, Figma)
Background: Mihika Kapoor is a design-engineer-PM hybrid at Figma, where she's known as the go-to person for leading zero-to-one products. She was an early PM on FigJam and is currently spearheading a new product launching in 2024. Prior to Figma, she was a Rotational Product Manager at Meta working on commerce and creators, and founded Design Nation‚Äîa national nonprofit that democratizes undergraduate access to design education. She majored in CS and minored in visual arts at Princeton, embodying a left-brain/right-brain approach that defines her product style. Colleagues describe her as beloved, extremely driven, and able to create compelling visions that get people to see what she sees.
Communication Style: Direct, enthusiastic, and unapologetically passionate‚Äînever sugarcoats anything or says she likes something if she doesn't. Explicitly communicates confidence levels ('I feel medium confidence on this, so if you feel stronger, I defer to you'). Sets expectations upfront about communication style ('I'm very direct, and if you disagree with me, I want to know that'). Creates two-way feedback culture by asking 'do you have feedback for me?' before giving feedback. Acts on feedback immediately to incentivize others to do same. Uses vivid metaphors (flames, Hestia, birthday parties for products). Shows vulnerability about weaknesses (high conviction can seem pushy, scrappy can mean last-minute, detail-obsessed can mean can't defer). Believes directness only works if it's two-way.

Name: Mike Krieger
Keywords: a/b testing, competition, differentiation, funnel, growth, management, metrics, mission, okrs, positioning, retention, revenue, roadmap, strategy, subscription
Description: Mike Krieger is the chief product officer of Anthropic and the co-founder of Instagram. After leaving Meta, he co-founded Artifact, an AI-powered news app that I absolutely loved, and joined...
Episode Title: Anthropic's CPO on what comes next | Mike Krieger (co-founder of Instagram)
Background: Mike Krieger is the Chief Product Officer at Anthropic and co-founder of Instagram, where he built one of the most iconic consumer products of the last decade. After leaving Meta, he co-founded Artifact, an AI-powered news app that personalized content discovery in ways that captured the joy of Google Reader, before shutting it down to join Anthropic in 2024. At Anthropic, he leads product for Claude, working at the bleeding edge of AI product development where 90% of code is now written by AI (95%+ for Claude Code itself). He brings a rare combination of consumer product intuition, deep technical understanding, and founder humility‚Äîwilling to call things when they're not working while pushing the boundaries of what's possible with AI.
Communication Style: Thoughtful and humble while being at the bleeding edge. Balances founder intensity ('you need existential energy, you can't instill it with OKRs') with measured reflection ('I probably made some changes too slowly, should have reorganized product earlier'). Uses vivid metaphors (patient zero, MCP'd, Claude has no chill) to make abstract concepts concrete. References his own failures openly (Artifact, ego bruise of shutting things down) without dwelling on them. Brings both technical depth (TypeScript, merge queues, post-training) and human empathy (the kid discovering they love poetry at 3am, not everything meaningful shows up in metrics). Excited and genuine when describing cool stuff (Boris building Claude Code, Rick Rubin collab, the engineer screaming about Opus 4). Self-aware about role shifts (everyone expected him to go super hard on consumer, he made the other mistake). Integrates parenting and human values into tech conversation naturally (breakfast questions with his 6-year-old, nurturing curiosity over automation).

Name: Mike Maples Jr
Keywords: acquisition, activation, conversion, design, growth, leadership, management, market, mission, positioning, pricing, revenue, roadmap, strategy, vision
Description: Mike Maples, Jr. is a legendary early-stage startup investor and a co-founder and partner at Floodgate. He‚Äôs made early bets on transformative companies like Twitter, Lyft, Twitch, Okta,...
Episode Title: Pattern Breakers: How to find a breakthrough startup idea | Mike Maples, Jr. (Partner at Floodgate)
Background: Mike Maples Jr. is a legendary early-stage startup investor and co-founder/partner at Floodgate, founded over 20 years ago as one of the earliest pioneers of seed investing as a category. He's made early bets on transformative companies like Twitter, Lyft, Twitch, Okta, Rappi, and Applied Intuition, and has been on the Forbes Midas List eight times. After Twitch was acquired for $970M (making 85x returns on a company he'd forgotten he was a shareholder of), he embarked on a decade-long research project: he collected pitch decks from any startup where you would've made over 100x on your first check, creating time capsules of what these companies looked like at the precise moment you'd need to decide if they were interesting‚Äînot after they succeeded. He analyzed these patterns across thousands of startups to understand where breakthrough ideas come from and what separates startups that change the world from those that go nowhere. His finding: 80% of his biggest exit profits came from pivots, and the successful companies didn't follow best practices. He's an authentic 'train spotter' for startups, maintaining databases and conducting informal interviews with founders over years to understand the unvarnished wild story of what really happened.
Communication Style: Storyteller with academic rigor meets folksy wisdom. Uses vivid metaphors (banana vs. apple, David's slingshot with inflection as rock, Jonathan Livingston Seagull). Self-deprecating about missed investments (Airbnb at $1.5M valuation, 'this hurts,' would've made 6,000x). Embraces the 'train spotter' identity‚Äîdorky obsession with startup databases, pitch deck time capsules. Patient teacher willing to stress test ideas without judgment ('It's not my place to have opinion, but let me ask you'). Intellectual curiosity about root causes (asks founders 'When did you make that change?' not 'Why were you successful?'). References wide range (William Gibson, Louis Pasteur, Scott Cook, Nancy Duarte, Abe Lincoln, Star Wars, Steve Jobs). Willing to be contrarian (most people think visionaries have special binoculars‚Äîwrong, they get hands dirty). Credits others generously (Nancy Duarte helped him understand storytelling, Scott Cook taught him about surprises). Honest about the loneliness and criticism founders face before and after success.

Name: Molly Graham

She's direct and honest about the emotional difficulty of leadership while providing practical tools. She uses personal stories and concrete examples from her experience at major tech companies. Her tone is supportive but realistic, acknowledging that growth and change are inherently painful while providing frameworks to navigate them effectively.

Name: Nan Yu

Admits to being a 'conductor' who leads from behind and elevates others, which she's working to balance with leading from the front when needed. Deeply thoughtful about developing her own first-party perspective rather than outsourcing thinking through process. Emphasizes that process should make teams faster, not slower.

Communication Style: Warm, vulnerable, and radically practical. Openly shares mom's story, client struggles, hard truths about market. Uses 'I' language‚Äîpersonal, not distant expert. Lots of counterintuitive advice flagged explicitly ('I'm queen of counterintuitive stuff'). Passionate about mission but grounded in data (2,000 councils, 87% negotiation success rate, 3-month average vs. 3-6 national). Not afraid to call out uncomfortable truths: 'Your candidate market fit is terrible.' 'The market is clear: only role you're fit for is company about to go bankrupt.' Balances brutal honesty with deep empathy: 'Not personal judgment‚Äîit's the market.' Constantly reminds people what they're feeling is universal: 'Everyone, no matter how senior, feels insecure.' Uses product language extensively (PMF, iterate, customer feedback, market research, ICP). Engages directly with resistance: 'You might not think this is radical, but most people don't do it.' 'Every bone in your body will resist.' Repeats key points for emphasis. Uses examples extensively‚Äîname-drops specific people with permission, tells detailed stories. Generous‚Äîgives away methodology, templates, community for free. On campaign to get other 50% to do job mission with OKRs. Asks rhetorical questions to audience: 'Can you imagine? I'm asking people to raise hands.' Not polished corporate‚Äîhonest about what doesn't work, what's hard, where people struggle.

Background: Sean Ellis is one of the earliest and most influential thinkers and operators in growth. He coined the term 'growth hacking,' invented the ICE prioritization framework (Impact, Confidence, Ease), was one of the earliest people to use freemium as a growth strategy, and developed the famous 'Sean Ellis test' to measure product-market fit‚Äîa simple survey question ('How would you feel if you could no longer use this product?') that a large percentage of founders use today. Over his career, Sean was head of growth at Dropbox and Eventbrite, worked with companies like Microsoft and Nubank, was on the founding team of LogMeIn (sold for $4 billion+), and authored Hacking Growth, one of the most popular growth books ever written. His writing indirectly influenced TikTok's early growth team in Singapore, who said 'all the early stuff we did to grow TikTok was based on your writing.' His approach centers on being intensely curious about customers, asking the right questions at the right time, and building sustainable growth engines by optimizing the entire funnel‚Äînot just acquisition.
Communication Style: Intensely curious, practical, and anti-complexity. Sean is a relentless question-asker who digs into customers through surveys, interviews, and data to deeply understand what's working and why. He simplifies ruthlessly‚Äîthe Sean Ellis test is one question, ICE is three variables, his advice is direct ('ignore the somewhat disappointed users,' 'customer acquisition is the last step'). He came from outside Silicon Valley (Eastern Europe, New York, Boston) and brings a pragmatic 'if it's not useful, it won't succeed long-term' perspective, contrasting with Silicon Valley's love of cool technology for its own sake. He's a builder who gets hands-on, going all-in full-time for 3-6 months with early-stage companies post-PMF, purposely burning himself out, then recharging through teaching workshops. He's a methodical optimizer: he ran surveys multiple times a month at Dropbox to track how user segments evolved, he breaks down growth into systematic steps, he believes in high-velocity testing but emphasizes better tests over just more tests. His examples are always concrete (Lookout going from 7% to 40% in two weeks, Xobni's 'drowning in email' hook, the Pack Gear Hanging Suitcase Organizer he loves for his 100K+ miles of travel). He's protective of his simple frameworks‚Äîwhen asked about RICE vs. ICE, he admits 'maybe I'm being protective of my original idea' but defends simplicity over unnecessary complexity.

Name: Seth Godin
Keywords: competition, culture, design, engineering, founder, leadership, management, market, metrics, mission, roadmap, startup, strategy, ui, ux
Description: Seth Godin is a legend. He‚Äôs a marketer, teacher, entrepreneur, and author of more than 20 books, including Purple Cow, Permission Marketing, and Linchpin. He also writes one of the most...
Episode Title: Seth Godin's best tactics for building remarkable products, strategies, brands and more
Background: Seth Godin is a legend in marketing, teaching, entrepreneurship, and authorship. He has written more than 20 books including Purple Cow, Permission Marketing, and Linchpin‚Äîbooks that have fundamentally shaped how marketers and product builders think. He writes one of the most popular marketing blogs in the world, publishing daily for over two decades (post #10,000 comes out in early 2025). He co-founded Yoyodyne, one of the first internet marketing companies, sold it to Yahoo, then served as VP of Direct Marketing at Yahoo. He founded Squidoo and The Carbon Almanac, and created the altMBA, an intensive online leadership workshop. Seth is known for crystallizing complex ideas into simple, memorable frameworks that shift how people see their work. His philosophy centers on making art (doing generous, creative work that might not work), seeking tension (the gap between what is and what could be), and building for the smallest viable audience rather than trying to please everyone.
Communication Style: Aphoristic, provocative, and deeply human. Seth speaks in memorable one-liners that reframe how you see the world ('Good taste is knowing what other people want just before they do,' 'Quality means meeting spec,' 'Tension is at the heart of every innovation'). He's direct without being harsh, challenging assumptions while remaining generous. His examples are concrete and often personal (his mom's nickname was Lenny, he worked with Wes for years, he's shipped 10,000 blog posts). He's unapologetically philosophical about work‚Äîhe talks about 'making art' and 'serving your audience' with a reverence that feels almost spiritual, yet grounds it in practical action (ship daily, meet spec, earn permission). There's a kindness in his voice even when delivering tough truths ('if you're saying RTFM to your customers, YOU made a mistake'). He references cultural figures (Martin Luther King Jr., jazz saxophonists, fabric designers) to illustrate points, showing the breadth of his thinking. He's self-aware about his privilege and platform, using it to encourage others to make their own art. Overall, he's a teacher at heart‚Äîsomeone who genuinely wants you to see the world differently and has spent decades honing how to deliver insights that stick.

Name: Stewart Butterfield
Keywords: acquisition, analytics, culture, growth, iteration, leadership, management, metrics, positioning, pricing, prioritization, revenue, strategy, user research, vision
Description: Stewart Butterfield is the co-founder of Slack and Flickr, two of the most influential products in internet history. After selling Slack to Salesforce in one of tech‚Äôs biggest acquisitions,...
Episode Title: Mental models for building products people love ft. Stewart Butterfield
Background: Stewart Butterfield is the co-founder of Flickr and Slack, two of the most influential products in internet history. He sold Slack to Salesforce in one of tech's biggest acquisitions. Born Dharma Jeremy Butterfield (changed name at 12 to be 'normal'), he studied art and science in college rather than computer science. Both his iconic companies emerged from pivots‚ÄîFlickr from a game called Game Neverending, Slack from a game called Glitch. He spent years in the 'wilderness' between successes, working on passion projects that didn't find commercial traction but taught him about what it takes to actually win. After leaving Salesforce 2.5 years ago, he's been focused on family (has a 2.5-year-old), philanthropy, personal creative art projects, and occasionally talking with Cal Henderson (Slack's CTO, worked together 23 years) about what's next. His defining characteristic as a product leader: an almost pathological dissatisfaction with how things work, whether it's his own products or others'. In 2014, when asked if Slack was being improved, he said: 'What we have right now is just a giant piece of shit. It's just terrible and we should be humiliated that we offer this to the public.' Team printed this on 40 sheets of paper and pasted it on the wall. To him, if you can't see almost limitless opportunities to improve, you shouldn't be designing the product.
Communication Style: Verbose and digressive by his own admission ('I know that I am verbose'), but the digressions are full of concrete examples and rants about specific product failures that illustrate his points. Uses vivid metaphors and stories (umbrella tilting, restaurant websites, teenager using Snapchat on jetway) to make abstract product concepts tangible. Self-deprecating (calls his name choice 'terrible,' references Trump when he keeps ranting about Google). Comfortable with strong language when appropriate ('it's fucking humiliating,' 'giant piece of shit'). Highly specific and detail-oriented‚Äîwill describe exactly what's wrong with Gmail time zone picker or Apple's 'Sleep' feature naming. Balances cynicism about how things work with genuine care about craft and user experience. Often circles back to connect ideas (utility curves ‚Üí divine discontent ‚Üí need for continued improvement). Creates memorable phrases that become organizational shorthand ('tilt your umbrella,' 'owner's delusion,' 'don't make me think,' 'hyper-realistic work-like activities'). Generous with attributing ideas to others (Bezos, Annie Duke, Positioning book, Don't Make Me Think book). References his working relationship with Cal Henderson across 23 years. Prefers concrete operator examples over abstract theory‚Äîwill go deep on how Slack Do Not Disturb rollout worked vs. pontificating about principles.

Description: Teresa Torres is an internationally acclaimed author, speaker, and coach. She teaches a structured and sustainable system for continuous discovery that helps product teams infuse their daily...
Episode Title: Build better products with continuous product discovery | Teresa Torres
Background: Teresa Torres is an internationally acclaimed author, speaker, coach, and teacher. She's the author of 'Continuous Discovery Habits,' the #1 most recommended book in Lenny's newsletter Slack community. Through Product Talk Academy, she's taught over 11,000 students, and through her coaching work, she's worked with hundreds of product teams. She teaches a structured and sustainable system for continuous discovery that helps product teams infuse customer feedback into their daily decision-making. She's one of the top five people in the world when it comes to the number of PMs she's worked with, taught, and impacted. Before coaching, she worked as a user researcher and has spent years developing methods to make customer-centric product development sustainable and scalable. Communication Style: Patient teacher who's realistic about difficulty ('I'm going to make you think harder than you've ever had to think at work'). Self-aware about how hard her methods are in practice despite looking simple ('I cry a little bit when I see blog posts using opportunity solution trees with opportunity space full of solutions'). Balances idealism ('imagine if this worked, imagine if this was possible') with pragmatism ('there really are teams that work this way‚ÄîI'm sorry you've never been exposed to it'). Willing to be a bit provocative to make points (kindergartners outperform MBA students on marshmallow test because MBAs spend time posturing about power instead of just doing). Uses concrete examples (Netflix, streaming entertainment) to make abstract concepts tangible. Emphasizes that interviewing is a grossly underestimated skill and demonstrates it by actually conducting mini-interview in the conversation. Frustrated by toxic business culture teaching siloed territory defense instead of collaboration. Admits she sounds 'Pollyanna naive' about product trios deciding together but has seen it work repeatedly.

Background: Todd Jackson is a partner at First Round Capital, bringing an exceptionally rare combination of operator and investor experience. He founded Cover in 2013 (funded by First Round), sold it to Twitter in 2014. After four years investing at First Round, he's worked with hundreds of early B2B founders. This unique vantage point‚Äîconsumer product at scale (Gmail, Facebook, Twitter), enterprise product (Dropbox), founder experience, and seed-stage VC pattern recognition across First Round's portfolio‚Äîpositions him to see what actually works versus what founders think should work. He created First Round's Product-Market Fit Method, a free 14-week program distilling decades of First Round portfolio data into actionable frameworks.
Communication Style: Exceptionally clear and structured‚Äîuses precise definitions, numbered frameworks, and concrete benchmarks (not vague advice). Balances operator empathy ('I've been there, I know this is hard') with investor pattern recognition ('here's what I've seen across hundreds of companies'). Generous with examples‚Äîevery concept illustrated with real First Round portfolio company stories (Vanta, Lattice, Ironclad, Looker, Persona, Verkada). Uses metaphors that stick ($100 vending machine, friend zone, boulder rolling uphill then downhill, happy ears, fish jumping in boat). Acknowledges uncomfortable truths directly (60% never get past L2, most pivots should be 200% not 10%, 'interesting' means no, no shame in returning money to investors). Quantifies everything possible‚Äîtimelines, ARR ranges, team sizes, conversion rates, metric benchmarks. Teaches through Socratic questioning‚Äîdemonstrates dollar-driven discovery live in conversation. Emphasizes this is science not just art, while respecting that execution is still incredibly hard.

Name: Varun Mohan

Background: Varun Mohan is co-founder and CEO of Windsurf (formerly Codeium), an AI-powered IDE that reached over 1 million users in just four months. Before Windsurf, he worked in autonomous vehicles and his co-founder worked on AR/VR at Meta. They started building GPU virtualization and compiler software, believing deep learning would transform industries. When generative AI emerged in mid-2022, they made a bold pivot‚Äîabandoning a profitable business with millions in revenue to build AI coding tools. They built their own models, scaled their own infrastructure, and eventually forked VSCode to create Windsurf when existing IDEs couldn't showcase their AI capabilities. With ~160 people (50+ engineers), they're competing directly with well-funded players like Cursor while maintaining enterprise relationships with companies like JPMorgan Chase and Dell.
Communication Style: Direct, thoughtful, systematic thinker who speaks in frameworks. Uses analogies from parallel computing (Amdahl's Law), machine learning (overfitting), and systems design. Isn't afraid to make bold statements about the future ('90% of code will be written by AI') but grounds them in current data and trends. Values clarity over politeness‚Äîwill directly say 'that's kind of stupid to believe' when evaluating unrealistic founder expectations. Comfortable with nuance ('it's this weird tightrope') and doesn't pretend to have all the answers. Often reflects on what he wishes he'd done sooner ('I wish we had made this decision a couple months earlier'). Balances confidence in execution with humility about predictions. No fluff‚Äîgets to the point and explains the 'why' behind decisions.
